A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets of paper for a separate questionnaire.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption. (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new names above in (1), (2), (3).

Fuller School was named after Admiral Fuller, a Civil War Navy man. The first teacher was Mrs. McClellan for $600 a year. The next teacher got $900 and paid over a month. The Board of Education raised the salary to $900 a year. The school was built in 1910-11. In 1916 there were 9 pupils, increasing to 21 in 1917. A year later it was enlarged to 160 pupils, increasing to 210 in 1918. It was enlarged again in 1919 to 280 pupils. The school had a coal furnace and tried to heat each other having several weeks before the fire started. The school was heated by a wood stove and was very cold during the winter.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

One thing is evident, namely everyone has a car and people get around more than in the horse and buggy days. I believe we got together and had more good times three days than now. We had Rotarians, dances, meetings. The next contact between pioneers will teach our community to get together a bit more than now.
